awd_titl_txt: Neutron Imaging Interferometry for Non-Destructive Testing
awd_abstract_narration:
Interferometry is a family of techniques in which waves are superimposed and cause a phenomenon of interference, which is used to extract information.  Neutrons show dual particle and wave nature.  They can be described as wave packets and show interference effects like X-rays and visible light.  The primary focus of this project is to analyze and maximize the neutron interferometric beamline performances with simulations and experiments. The research team will also establish biomedical applications, which include non-invasive imaging of a bone-implant interface, to facilitate the manufacture of hip replacement implants.  Within this project, the PI aims to build a novel comprehensive simulator allowing scatter and phase-shift of neutrons, suitable for realistic neutron interferometry and verified with experiments.  The PI and a graduate trainee will perform simulations and experiments on Neutron Interferometry Imaging at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Center for Neutron Research (NCNR).  First, a comprehensive computer simulator of neutron interferometry will be built by describing the neutron as a particle and a wave and verified. Second, special phase gratings will be investigated in simulations to improve Neutron Interferometric Tomography (NIT) performance.  Third, a bone-metal interface will be imaged using NIT.  This project will establish a strong neutron interferometric imaging program at Louisiana State University (LSU).  This project seeks to aid researchers from multiple disciplines (neutron imaging scientists and non-destructive testing application specialists) and is synergistic with Louisiana Consortium on Neutron Scattering and LSU Medical Physics.  It will establish a new research program for the PI and generate project software that will be disseminated on Github.  The future projects generated by this fellowship and collaboration with NIST will train undergraduate students, graduate students, and postdocs at LSU. 

A combined Monte-Carlo and coherent wave simulation exist for X-ray interferometry but not for neutron interferometry. The primary focus of this project is to analyze and maximize the neutron interferometric far-field imaging beamline performances with simulations and experiments.  The research team will also establish biomedical applications such as non-invasive ex-vivo test-imaging of a bone-implant interface, to facilitate the manufacture of hip replacement implants.  Simulations and experiments on Neutron Interferometry Imaging will be conducted at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Center for Neutron Research (NCNR).  First, a novel, comprehensive computer simulator will be built to describe the neutron as a particle, as well as a wave, and verified.  The simulator will include Monte-Carlo based neutron scattering, coherent wave interference, and vibration effects.  The simulations will be experimentally verified using dual-phase gratings existing in the system and other high-quality neutron phase gratings that are available on loan from Louisiana State University (LSU).  The simulator will predict the far-field visibility and differential phase contrast (DPC) sensitivity at the NIST beamline as well as for two beamlines at Oakridge National Laboratory (ORNL).  This objective advances the ORNL neutron imaging and scattering research, in synergy with the goals of the Louisiana Consortium of Neutron Scattering.  Second, the conditions for ideal DPC imaging will be investigated in simulations.  Special modulated phase gratings (MPG) will be evaluated to improve Neutron Interferometric Tomography (NIT) performance.  DPC sensitivity will be investigated as a function of grating pitch or pitches and spatial modulation of MPG.  Third, novel experiments will be conducted to observe a bone-metal interface ex-vivo with NIT at NIST.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summary

We demonstrated, through theory and simulations, a novel phase grating interferometer system for cold neutrons that requires a single modulated phase grating (MPG) for phase-contrast imaging, as opposed to the two or three phase gratings in previously employed phase grating

moiré interferometers (PGMI) systems. The system also outperformed the state-of-the art PGMI system at NIST. In comparing to the experimental results for with best-case visibility of around 39% for the PGMI at NIST, the MPG produced a higher visibility of 94.2% for comparable source to detector distance.

Our results are published in a 22-page paper. First and third authors are students Ivan Hidrovo and Hunter Meyer, advised by PI, and funded by this project.

[1]. Hidrovo*, J. Dey, H. Meyer*, D. S. Hussey, N. N. Klimov, L. Butler, K. Ham, W. D. Newhauser, “Neutron Interferometry using a Single Modulated Phase Grating”, Rev. Sci. Instrum. vol. 94, 045110, (2023), Published April 2023 https://doi.org/10.1063/5.0106706

*Direct students of PI J. Dey 

In this paper substantial mathematical theory was derived by student Hunter Meyer showing the dual modulation of MPG with a large period and a smaller carrier pitch P, resulting in large

fringes at the detector, visible without a second grating (either phase grating as in a PGMI or absorber grating as in a Talbot Lau interferometer). The theory (derived by Hunter) was compared to the full Sommerfeld–Rayleigh Diffraction Integral (SRDI) simulator (implemented by student Ivan Hidrovo). The mathematical model is about 1000 times faster to generate the interference patterns than the SRDI simulator.

Their respective contribution for this paper form Ivan Hidrovo (simulation) and Hunter Meyer (theory) form their respective MSc thesis work. Ivan Hidrovo graduated with MSc Summer 2022. Hunter Meyer will defend his MSc thesis (scheduled March 11, 2024) and continue working on neutron and x-ray interferometry for his PhD (expected graduation May 2025).

Another student, Maxwell Cole, helped and guided by the PI has worked on the simulator to include dual MPG gratings.

Major contributions

  • MSc/PhD student Hunter Meyer (current) has derived the mathematics behind a generalized phase grating with a generalized envelope modulation using the Fresnel approximation of Somerfield-Rayleigh Diffraction Integral. The mathematics is detailed in appendix of published paper above Ref [1]. The mathematical results have been compared to the full Somerfield Rayleigh Diffraction Integral. Hunter also derived the conditions of maximum visibility. The mathematical model is about 3 orders of magnitude faster than the SRDI simulator. This greatly facilitates the design and optimization of MPG systems.

 

  • The simulator implemented by Ivan Hidrovo (graduated Aug 2022) shows several operating points which improves the neutron interferometry performance (visibility for same interference fringe period) over the state-of-the-art neutron interferometry system in NIST.

 

Collaborations

 

Even though COVID-19 and subsequent system shut down of neutron reactor at NIST prevented us from visiting the NIST system, a strong collaboration has developed between NIST and PI’s group at LSU. PI and her students regularly attend and participate in the INFER meeting (once a month). Two students Ivan Hidrovo and Hunter Meyer presented their work at the INFER meeting. Dr. D. S. Hussey and Dr. N. N. Klimov are co-authors in the paper Ref [1].

 

Products

 

Two students have mainly worked on this project, Ivan Hidrovo (graduated with MSc, Aug 2022); MSc/PhD student Hunter Meyer (MSc thesis defense scheduled March 11, 2024; PhD defense expected May 2025). Another student Maxwell Cole also helped out with simulator.

 

We have the following products from this grant.

 

Peer Reviewed Journal Publication

 

I. Hidrovo*, J. Dey, H. Meyer*, D. S. Hussey, N. N. Klimov, L. Butler, K. Ham, W. D. Newhauser, “Neutron Interferometry using a Single Modulated Phase Grating”, Rev. Sci. Instrum. vol. 94, 045110, (2023), Published April 2023 https://doi.org/10.1063/5.0106706

*Direct students of PI J. Dey 

 

Thesis/Defense

  • Hidrovo Giler, Ivan J., "Neutron Interferometry Using a Single Modulated Phase Grating" (2022). LSU Master's Theses. 5630.  Advisor Dey, Joyoni, DOI:10.31390/gradschool_theses.5630, https://repository.lsu.edu/gradschool_theses/5630 [Defended July 2022]
  • Meyer, Hunter, “The Theory of X-ray and Neutron Interferometry Using a Modulated Phase Grating", MSc thesis defense scheduled March 11, 2024

 

Future research

This project has enabled future research directions on building and investigating Modulated Phase Grating (MPG) neutron interferometry. We will also build the mathematical theory for dual grating. This will allow us to investigate dual MPG systems to increase the range of length scales of small angle scatter that the system can interrogate.
